articles.headline: Turmoil Grows for Wolfowitz at World Bank
articles.snippet: Paul D. Wolfowitz apologized for his role in the raise and transfer of his companion, but was greeted by booing.
articles.abstract: Paul D. Wolfowitz apologized for his role in the raise and transfer of his companion, but was greeted by booing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 12 — Paul D. Wolfowitz’s tenure as president of the World Bank was thrown into turmoil on Thursday by the disclosure that he had helped arrange a pay raise for his companion at the time of her transfer from the bank to the State Department, where she remained on the bank payroll.

articles.headline: Dow Chemical Fires 2, Citing Talks on a Buyout
articles.snippet: Two senior executives were fired for holding a series of secret meetings about selling the company in a leveraged buyout.
articles.abstract: Two senior executives were fired for holding a series of secret meetings about selling the company in a leveraged buyout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last four months, two senior executives of the Dow Chemical Company held a series of secret meetings with investment bankers and prospective investors about selling the company in a leveraged buyout that would have been worth more than $52 billion.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Claudia H. Deutsch

articles.headline: 8 Iraqis Killed in Bomb Attack at Legislature
articles.snippet: An attack on Parliament was the worst in the International Zone since it was created four years ago.
articles.abstract: An attack on Parliament was the worst in the International Zone since it was created four years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 12 — A suicide bomber struck deep inside the heavily fortified International Zone on Thursday, killing eight people when he detonated his explosives inside the Parliament building, just a few feet from the main chamber.

articles.headline: Paranoia and Bugging at Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: It appears that the company grew paranoid about its critics, and created a security operation that went too far.
articles.abstract: It appears that the company grew paranoid about its critics, and created a security operation that went too far.

articles.headline: Off the Air: The Light Goes Out for Don Imus
articles.snippet: CBS yielded to pressure when it canceled “Imus in the Morning,” ending a program that had been broadcasting for more than 30 years.
articles.abstract: CBS yielded to pressure when it canceled “Imus in the Morning,” ending a program that had been broadcasting for more than 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: CBS brought a weeklong confrontation over a racial and sexual insult by the radio host Don Imus to an end yesterday when it canceled the “Imus in the Morning” program, effective immediately.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg

articles.headline: Flying Solo Past the Point of No Return
articles.snippet: Don Imus never caught a breath because he was in the gunsights of a 24-hour news cycle.
articles.abstract: Don Imus never caught a breath because he was in the gunsights of a 24-hour news cycle.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a few days, it seemed as if Don Imus would somehow pull out of the death spiral. After all, once he came under fire, Mr. Imus said he was sorry for the racial insult, said he was sorry again and then began a week of penance, raising money on his own show for sick children and turning up at various other microphones to renew his apology.

articles.headline: Germany’s Export-Led Economy Finds Global Niche
articles.snippet: A small town in eastern Germany showcases the strengths of a resurgent economy.
articles.abstract: A small town in eastern Germany showcases the strengths of a resurgent economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: JENA, Germany — For those seeking the elixir that has given new life to Germany’s economy, a visit to this ancient university town in the eastern part of the country would be a good place to start.

articles.headline: Sallie Mae Said to Talk to Suitors
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest lender to college students is in talks to be taken private in what could be a $20 billion deal.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest lender to college students is in talks to be taken private in what could be a $20 billion deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion, people briefed on the discussions said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced
